title: FIXED: message limit issue
message:
FIXED: message limit issue

Message limit was built to support only one contact (making use of sqlite's 'min' function). It will now properly update the messages (delete old ones in order to maintain the max number of messages). However, 1 is the lowest message limit (0 is still accepted but is treated as 1). Finally, messages are not 'actively' deleted, which means if the threshold is lower then the previous threshold there will be no apparent changes (the oldest message will be deleted and replaced by the newest one).

title: Completed the key exchange, now key exchanges have a CRC32 checksum
message:
Completed the key exchange, now key exchanges have a CRC32 checksum

Completed the hex exchange, now key exchanges also have an additional
CRC32 checksum, which is used to check if an incoming message is
a key exchange message or not.

The new format of key exchange messages is the following:

      -------------------------------------
      | public key | signature | checksum |
      -------------------------------------

Where the public key and signature calculation are the same, but
a CRC32 checksum of the signed public key is calculated. The
entire key exchange message is then encoded as Base64 for
transmission.

title: Attempted to improve security by using both pieces of shared info
message:
Attempted to improve security by using both pieces of shared info

This is a temporary fix to help improve the security of the ECG key
exchange by using both piece of the a priori shared information to
sign & verify the public keys (S1 + S2) instead of just S1 or S2
depending on if you are the initiator or recipient.

This is still a security flaw, as the weakest part of the cryptosystem
is the shared information that the users specify. If an attacker breaks
the shared information then there are multiple attack vectors on the
cryptosystem. To put it bluntly, if an attacker breaks the shared
information used and somehow has access to the public keys the entire
cryptosystem is broken.

A potential solution may be to integrate gesture input for entering
the shared information S1 & S2.

title: Accidentally forgot to mention in last commit

Accidentally forgot to mention in last commit

ADD: Added my own custom sign/verifiable public key exchange for ECC when using the ECIES implementation. Because ECIES is being used public key are signed and verified using the shared information S1 if initiating the key exchange or S2 if responding to a key exchange.

It's not as eloquent as Diffie-Hellman exchange, but it works, please read the notes below as well.

NOTE: Since ECIES is being used,the two shared information values S1 and S2 makes it possible to sign and verify public keys. If both users specify two secure (non-trivial or blank) shared information variables S1 and S2 then it makes a man-in-the-middle attack VERY difficult, signing public keys is something ECHD does not support, this is my own sign/verify scheme, lets call it ECG exchange.

NOTE: Users can choose not to provide two shared information (shared passphrases) values, but it makes it impossible to sign/verify the public keys.

NOTE: The key exchange scheme is flawed if only one S value is provided (S1 or S2) as you could determine that the S value is null because the hash would pass without an S1 or S2 given. Therefore a user MUST specify an S1 and S2 OR not specify an S value AT ALL. I would like to make S1 and S2 mandatory.

NOTE: To maintain 256-bit security level for our project each passphrase (S1/S2) can and SHOULD be 32 characters long.
